ControlledConcept.gml:description: process that effects the geologic record Source: this vocabulary
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:EventProcess:200811:geologic_process
ControlledConcept.name: Geologic Process

ControlledConcept.gml:description: Process of disappearance of a species or higher taxon, so that it no longer exists anywhere or in the subsequent fossil record. Source: this vocabulary
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:EventProcess:200811:extinction
ControlledConcept.name: extinction

ControlledConcept.gml:description: process that results inappearance of new species Source: this vocabulary
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:EventProcess:200811:speciation
ControlledConcept.name: speciation

ControlledConcept.gml:description: Process of removal of oxygen from from the deep part of a body of water. Source: this vocabulary
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:EventProcess:200811:deep_water_oxygen_depletion
ControlledConcept.name: deep water oxygen depletion

ControlledConcept.gml:description: process of mean sea level changing relative to some datum Source: this vocabulary
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:EventProcess:200811:sea_level_change
ControlledConcept.name: sea level change

ControlledConcept.gml:description: process of mean sea level rising relative to some datum Source: this vocabulary
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:EventProcess:200811:sea_level_rise
ControlledConcept.name: sea level rise

ControlledConcept.gml:description: process of mean sea level falling relative to some datum Source: this vocabulary
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:EventProcess:200811:sea_level_fall
ControlledConcept.name: sea level fall

ControlledConcept.gml:description: a phenomenon that changes the distribution or physical properties of sediment at or near the earth's surface Source: this vocabulary
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:EventProcess:200811:sedimentary_process
ControlledConcept.name: sedimentary process

ControlledConcept.gml:description: The process of disaggregation of rock and displacement of the resultant particles (sediment) usually by the agents of currents such as, wind, water, or ice by downward or down-slope movement in response to gravity or by living organisms (in the case of bioerosion). Source: this vocabulary
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:EventProcess:200811:erosion
ControlledConcept.name: erosion

ControlledConcept.gml:description: Erosion by clast impact or plucking by moving liquid water Source: this vocabulary
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:EventProcess:200811:water_erosion
ControlledConcept.name: water erosion

ControlledConcept.gml:description: Erosion by clast impact or plucking by moving air (wind) Source: this vocabulary
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:EventProcess:200811:wind_erosion
ControlledConcept.name: wind erosion

ControlledConcept.gml:description: Erosion by corrasion or plucking by moving ice. Source: this vocabulary
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:EventProcess:200811:ice_erosion
ControlledConcept.name: ice erosion

ControlledConcept.gml:description: the dislodgement and downslope transport of soil and rock material under the direct application of gravitational body stresses. In contrast to other erosion processes, the debris removed by mass wasting is not carried within, on, or under another medium. The mass properties of the material being transported depend on the interaction of the soil and rock particles and on the moisture content. Source: Neuendorf, K.K.E, Mehl, J.P. & Jackson, J.A. (eds), 2005. Glossary of geology, 5th Edition. American Geological Institute, Alexandria, 779 p.
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:EventProcess:200811:mass_wasting
ControlledConcept.name: mass wasting

ControlledConcept.gml:description: downslope transport, under gravitational influence, of soil and rock material en masse over a relatively confined zone or surface of shear. Source: Neuendorf, K.K.E, Mehl, J.P. & Jackson, J.A. (eds), 2005. Glossary of geology, 5th Edition. American Geological Institute, Alexandria, 779 p.
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:EventProcess:200811:slide
ControlledConcept.name: slide

ControlledConcept.gml:description: The relatively free falling or precipitous movement of a newly detached segment of bedrock (usually massive, homogeneous, or jointed) of any size from a cliff or other very steep slope; it is the fastest form of mass movement and is most frequent in mountain areas and during spring when there is repeated freezing and thawing of water in cracks in the rock. Movement may be straight down, or in a series of leaps and bounds down the slope; it is not guided by an underlying slip surface Source: Neuendorf, K.K.E, Mehl, J.P. & Jackson, J.A. (eds), 2005. Glossary of geology, 5th Edition. American Geological Institute, Alexandria, 779 p.
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:EventProcess:200811:fall
ControlledConcept.name: fall

ControlledConcept.gml:description: a process characterized by a flowing mass of predominantly fine-grained earth material possessing a high degree of fluidity during movement. The water content of mudflows may range up to 60%. The degree of water bonding, determined by the clay content and mineralogy, critically affects the viscosity of the matrix and the velocity and morphology of the flow. (Neuendorf et al 2005) Source: Neuendorf, K.K.E, Mehl, J.P. & Jackson, J.A. (eds), 2005. Glossary of geology, 5th Edition. American Geological Institute, Alexandria, 779 p.
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:EventProcess:200811:mud_flow
ControlledConcept.name: mud flow

ControlledConcept.gml:description: Process of downslope transport of silt to boulder size particles in a matrix of clay-grade fines and water, characterized by a matrix that sufficient has strength and buoyancy to support grains; particle support also by intergranular collision; matrix 'lubricates' moving sediment mass. Leeder, 1982; p76 Source: Leeder, 1982
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:EventProcess:200811:debris_flow
ControlledConcept.name: debris flow

ControlledConcept.gml:description: Process of slow, more or less continuous downslope movement of mineral, rock, and soil particles under gravitational stresses. (Neuendorf et al 2005). Typically loose material produced by weathering and erosion is transported and deposited by tumbling, rolling, settling, particle creep, under the influence of gravitational forces with or without the assistance of aqueous slope wash. (NADM SLTTs, 2004) Source: NADM SLTTs 2004
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:EventProcess:200811:creep
ControlledConcept.name: creep

ControlledConcept.gml:description: Process of downslope movement of a mass of sediment particles set in motion by gravity when depositional slope exceeds a critical angle; flow characterized by grain-grain collisions. Leeder 1982, p76 Source: Leeder, 1982
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:EventProcess:200811:grain_flow
ControlledConcept.name: grain flow

ControlledConcept.gml:description: process of slow viscous downslope flow of waterlogged soil and other unsorted and saturated surficial material, normally at 0.5-5.0 cm/yr; especially on slopes underlain by frozen ground that acts as a downward barrier to water percolation, initiated by frost action and augmented by meltwater resulting from alternate freezing and thawing of snow and ground ice. Source: Neuendorf, K.K.E, Mehl, J.P. & Jackson, J.A. (eds), 2005. Glossary of geology, 5th Edition. American Geological Institute, Alexandria, 779 p.
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:EventProcess:200811:solifluction
ControlledConcept.name: solifluction

ControlledConcept.gml:description: Accumulation of material; the constructive process of accumulation of sedimentary particles, chemical precipitation of mineral matter from solution, or the accumulation of organic material on the death of plants and animals. Source: Neuendorf, K.K.E, Mehl, J.P. & Jackson, J.A. (eds), 2005. Glossary of geology, 5th Edition. American Geological Institute, Alexandria, 779 p.
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:EventProcess:200811:deposition
ControlledConcept.name: deposition

ControlledConcept.gml:description: process by which material that is being transported as particles by moving air, water, ice, or other fluid comes to rest and accumulates (NADM SLTTs 2004) Source: NADM SLTTs 2004
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:EventProcess:200811:mechanical_deposition
ControlledConcept.name: mechanical deposition

ControlledConcept.gml:description: the deposition of mineral matter by precipitation from solution, or the accumulation of organic material on the death of plants and animals. Source: Neuendorf, K.K.E, Mehl, J.P. & Jackson, J.A. (eds), 2005. Glossary of geology, 5th Edition. American Geological Institute, Alexandria, 779 p.
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:EventProcess:200811:chemical_precipitation
ControlledConcept.name: chemical precipitation

ControlledConcept.gml:description: the deposition of minerals from solution by the agency of organisms Source: this vocabulary
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:EventProcess:200811:biological_precipitation
ControlledConcept.name: biological precipitation

ControlledConcept.gml:description: Any chemical, physical, or biological process that affects a sedimentary EarthMaterial after initial deposition, and during or after lithification, exclusive of weathering and metamorphism. [adapt. Jackson, 1997] Example processes include compaction, cementation, authigenesis, replacement, leaching, hydration, and bacterial action. Includes processes that are normal in the surficial or outer part of the earth’s crust [Jackson, 1997]. Changes in a deeply buried sedimentary rock may be continuous from diagenesis into recrystallization to form a metamorphic rock. Robertson [1999] defines the boundary between diagenesis and metamorphism in sedimentary rocks as follows: "the boundary between diagenesis and metamorphism is somewhat arbitrary and strongly dependent on the rock types involved. For example changes take place in organic materials at lower temperatures than in rocks dominated by silicate minerals. In mudrocks, a white mica (illite) crystallinity value of less than 0.42D.2U obtained by X-ray diffraction analysis, is used to define the onset of metamorphism (Kisch, 1991). In this scheme, the first appearance of glaucophane, lawsonite, paragonite, prehnite, pumpellyite or stilpnomelane is taken to indicate the lower limit of metamorphism (Frey and Kisch, 1987; Bucher and Frey, 1994; Frey and Robinson, 1998). Most workers agree that such mineral growth starts at 150 ± 50° C in silicate rocks. Many rock types may show no change in mineralogy under these conditions and hence the recognition of the onset of metamorphism will vary with bulk composition." Source: Neuendorf, K.K.E, Mehl, J.P. & Jackson, J.A. (eds), 2005. Glossary of geology, 5th Edition. American Geological Institute, Alexandria, 779 p.
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:EventProcess:200811:diagenetic_process
ControlledConcept.name: Diagenetic process

ControlledConcept.gml:description: process that results in change in Earth's magnetic field Source: this vocabulary
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:EventProcess:200811:geomagnetic_process
ControlledConcept.name: geomagnetic process

ControlledConcept.gml:description: process of migration of the axis of the earth's dipole field relative to the rotation axis of the Earth. Source: this vocabulary
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:EventProcess:200811:polar_wander
ControlledConcept.name: polar wander

ControlledConcept.gml:description: geomagnetic event Source: this vocabulary
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:EventProcess:200811:magnetic_field_reversal
ControlledConcept.name: magnetic field reversal

ControlledConcept.gml:description: A process involving melted rock (magma). Source: this vocabulary
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:EventProcess:200811:magmatic_process
ControlledConcept.name: magmatic process

ControlledConcept.gml:description: The process of emplacement of magma in pre-existing rock Source: Neuendorf, K.K.E, Mehl, J.P. & Jackson, J.A. (eds), 2005. Glossary of geology, 5th Edition. American Geological Institute, Alexandria, 779 p.
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:EventProcess:200811:intrusion
ControlledConcept.name: intrusion

ControlledConcept.gml:description: The ejection of volcanic materials (lava, pyroclasts, and volcanic gases) onto the Earth's surface, either from a central vent or from a fissure or group of fissures Source: Neuendorf, K.K.E, Mehl, J.P. & Jackson, J.A. (eds), 2005. Glossary of geology, 5th Edition. American Geological Institute, Alexandria, 779 p.
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:EventProcess:200811:eruption
ControlledConcept.name: eruption

ControlledConcept.gml:description: Eruption produced by the generation and rapid expansion of a gas phase that disrupts magma, surrounding wall rock or sediment Source: Orton, G.J., 1996. Volcanic environments. 485-567 in Reading, H.G. (ed.), Sedimentary Environments: Processes, Facies and Stratigraphy, Third Edition. Blackwell Science, Oxford
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:EventProcess:200811:pyroclastic_eruption
ControlledConcept.name: pyroclastic eruption

ControlledConcept.gml:description: Eruption characterized by the explosive ejection of fragments of new lava, commonly incandescent when they leave the vent but either solid or too viscous to assume any appreciable degree of rounding during their flight through the air. With these there are often breadcrust bombs or blocks, and generally large proportions of ash Source: Neuendorf, K.K.E, Mehl, J.P. & Jackson, J.A. (eds), 2005. Glossary of geology, 5th Edition. American Geological Institute, Alexandria, 779 p.
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:EventProcess:200811:vulcanian_eruption
ControlledConcept.name: vulcanian eruption

ControlledConcept.gml:description: An explosive eruption in which a steady, turbulent stream of fragmented magma and magmatic gas is released at a high velocity from a vent. Large volumes of tephra and tall eruption columns are characteristic Source: Neuendorf, K.K.E, Mehl, J.P. & Jackson, J.A. (eds), 2005. Glossary of geology, 5th Edition. American Geological Institute, Alexandria, 779 p.
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:EventProcess:200811:plinian_eruption
ControlledConcept.name: plinian eruption

ControlledConcept.gml:description: Eruption in which great quantities of extremely fluid basaltic lava are poured out, mainly issuing in lava fountains from fissures on the flanks of a volcano. Explosive phenomena are rare, but much spatter and scoria are piled into cones and mounds along the vents. Characteristic of shield volcanoes Source: Neuendorf, K.K.E, Mehl, J.P. & Jackson, J.A. (eds), 2005. Glossary of geology, 5th Edition. American Geological Institute, Alexandria, 779 p.
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:EventProcess:200811:hawaiian_eruption
ControlledConcept.name: hawaiian eruption

ControlledConcept.gml:description: Eruption characterized by jetting of clots or "fountains" of fluid, basaltic lava from a central crater Source: Neuendorf, K.K.E, Mehl, J.P. & Jackson, J.A. (eds), 2005. Glossary of geology, 5th Edition. American Geological Institute, Alexandria, 779 p.
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:EventProcess:200811:strombolian_eruption
ControlledConcept.name: strombolian eruption

ControlledConcept.gml:description: Eruptions characterized by low volatile content of the erupting magma relative to ambient pressure Source: Orton, G.J., 1996. Volcanic environments. 485-567 in Reading, H.G. (ed.), Sedimentary Environments: Processes, Facies and Stratigraphy, Third Edition. Blackwell Science, Oxford
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:EventProcess:200811:effusive_eruption
ControlledConcept.name: effusive eruption

ControlledConcept.gml:description: change of state from a solid to a liquid Source: this vocabulary
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:EventProcess:200811:melting
ControlledConcept.name: melting

ControlledConcept.gml:description: Process of melting involving only some of the mineral phases in a rock, to produce a mixture of melt and residual particles. Source: Neuendorf, K.K.E, Mehl, J.P. & Jackson, J.A. (eds), 2005. Glossary of geology, 5th Edition. American Geological Institute, Alexandria, 779 p.
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:EventProcess:200811:partial_melting
ControlledConcept.name: partial melting

ControlledConcept.gml:description: The process by which matter becomes crystalline, from a gaseous, fluid, or dispersed state Source: Neuendorf, K.K.E, Mehl, J.P. & Jackson, J.A. (eds), 2005. Glossary of geology, 5th Edition. American Geological Institute, Alexandria, 779 p.
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:EventProcess:200811:magmatic_crystallisation
ControlledConcept.name: magmatic crystallisation

ControlledConcept.gml:description: processes related to the interaction or deformation of rigid plates forming the crust of the earth. Source: this vocabulary
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:EventProcess:200811:tectonic_process
ControlledConcept.name: tectonic process

ControlledConcept.gml:description: The addition of material to a continent. Typically involves convergent or transform motion. Source: Neuendorf, K.K.E, Mehl, J.P. & Jackson, J.A. (eds), 2005. Glossary of geology, 5th Edition. American Geological Institute, Alexandria, 779 p.
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:EventProcess:200811:accretion
ControlledConcept.name: accretion

ControlledConcept.gml:description: The amalgamation of two continental plates or blocks along a convergent margin. Source: this vocabulary
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:EventProcess:200811:continental_collision
ControlledConcept.name: continental collision

ControlledConcept.gml:description: Fragmentation of a continental plate into two or more smaller plates; may involve rifting or strike slip faulting. Source: this vocabulary
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:EventProcess:200811:continental_breakup
ControlledConcept.name: continental breakup

ControlledConcept.gml:description: Extension of the crust to form one or more long, narrow graben of regional extent. Source: Neuendorf, K.K.E, Mehl, J.P. & Jackson, J.A. (eds), 2005. Glossary of geology, 5th Edition. American Geological Institute, Alexandria, 779 p.
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:EventProcess:200811:rifting
ControlledConcept.name: rifting

ControlledConcept.gml:description: A strike-slip fault that links two other faults or two other plate boundaries (e.g. two segments of a mid-ocean ridge). Transform faults often exhibit characteristics that distinguish them from transcurrent faults: (1) For transform faults formed at the same time as the faults they link, slip on the transform fault has equal magnitude at all points along the transform; slip magnitude on the transform fault can exceed the length of the transform fault, and slip does not decrease to zero at the fault termini. (2) For transform faults linking two similar features, e.g. if two mid-ocean ridge segments linked by a transform have equal spreading rates, then the length of the transform does not change as slip accrues on it. Source: Neuendorf, K.K.E, Mehl, J.P. & Jackson, J.A. (eds), 2005. Glossary of geology, 5th Edition. American Geological Institute, Alexandria, 779 p.
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:EventProcess:200811:transform_faulting
ControlledConcept.name: transform faulting

ControlledConcept.gml:description: The process of one lithospheric plate descending beneath another Source: Neuendorf, K.K.E, Mehl, J.P. & Jackson, J.A. (eds), 2005. Glossary of geology, 5th Edition. American Geological Institute, Alexandria, 779 p.
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:EventProcess:200811:subduction
ControlledConcept.name: subduction

ControlledConcept.gml:description: A process whereby new oceanic crust is formed by upwelling of magma at the center of mid-ocean ridges and by a moving-away of the new material from the site of upwelling at rates of one to ten centimeters per year. Source: Neuendorf, K.K.E, Mehl, J.P. & Jackson, J.A. (eds), 2005. Glossary of geology, 5th Edition. American Geological Institute, Alexandria, 779 p.
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:EventProcess:200811:spreading
ControlledConcept.name: spreading

ControlledConcept.gml:description: Mineralogical, chemical, and structural adjustment of solid rocks to physical and chemical conditions that differ from the conditions under which the rocks in question originated, and are generally been imposed at depth, below the surface zones of weathering and cementation. Source: this vocabulary
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:EventProcess:200811:metamorphic_process
ControlledConcept.name: metamorphic process

ControlledConcept.gml:description: Metamorphism taking place in rocks at or near their contact with a genetically related body of igneous rock Source: Neuendorf, K.K.E, Mehl, J.P. & Jackson, J.A. (eds), 2005. Glossary of geology, 5th Edition. American Geological Institute, Alexandria, 779 p.
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:EventProcess:200811:contact_metamorphism
ControlledConcept.name: contact metamorphism

ControlledConcept.gml:description: Metamorphism concentrated along narrow belts of shearing or crushing without an appreciable rise in temperature Source: Neuendorf, K.K.E, Mehl, J.P. & Jackson, J.A. (eds), 2005. Glossary of geology, 5th Edition. American Geological Institute, Alexandria, 779 p.
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:EventProcess:200811:dislocation_metamorphism
ControlledConcept.name: dislocation metamorphism

ControlledConcept.gml:description: General term for any change in the mineralogical or chemical composition of a rock. Typically related to interaction with hydrous fluids. Source: Fettes and Desmons, 2007
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:EventProcess:200811:alteration
ControlledConcept.name: alteration

ControlledConcept.gml:description: Movement of rock bodies by displacement on fault or shear zones, or change in shape of a body of Earth material. Source: this vocabulary
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:EventProcess:200811:deformation
ControlledConcept.name: deformation

ControlledConcept.gml:description: The formation of a surface of failure resulting from stress Source: this vocabulary
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:EventProcess:200811:fracturing
ControlledConcept.name: fracturing

ControlledConcept.gml:description: Development of fractures within a single grain or cutting several grains. Source: Neuendorf, K.K.E, Mehl, J.P. & Jackson, J.A. (eds), 2005. Glossary of geology, 5th Edition. American Geological Institute, Alexandria, 779 p.
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:EventProcess:200811:microfracturing
ControlledConcept.name: microfracturing

ControlledConcept.gml:description: The process of fracturing, frictional slip, and displacement accumulation that produces a fault Source: Neuendorf, K.K.E, Mehl, J.P. & Jackson, J.A. (eds), 2005. Glossary of geology, 5th Edition. American Geological Institute, Alexandria, 779 p.
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:EventProcess:200811:faulting
ControlledConcept.name: faulting

ControlledConcept.gml:description: A deformation in which contiguous parts of a body are displaced relatively to each other in a direction parallel to a surface. The surface may be a discrete fault, or the deformation may be a penetrative strain and the shear surface is a geometric abstraction. Source: Neuendorf, K.K.E, Mehl, J.P. & Jackson, J.A. (eds), 2005. Glossary of geology, 5th Edition. American Geological Institute, Alexandria, 779 p.
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:EventProcess:200811:shearing
ControlledConcept.name: shearing

ControlledConcept.gml:description: deformation without apparent loss of continuity at the scale of observation. Source: Neuendorf, K.K.E, Mehl, J.P. & Jackson, J.A. (eds), 2005. Glossary of geology, 5th Edition. American Geological Institute, Alexandria, 779 p.
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:EventProcess:200811:ductile_flow
ControlledConcept.name: ductile flow

ControlledConcept.gml:description: Deformation of a crystal by gliding to produce crystallographic twinning. Source: Neuendorf, K.K.E, Mehl, J.P. & Jackson, J.A. (eds), 2005. Glossary of geology, 5th Edition. American Geological Institute, Alexandria, 779 p.
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:EventProcess:200811:deformation_twinning
ControlledConcept.name: deformation twinning

ControlledConcept.gml:description: Grain-scale, ductile deformation accomplished by the motion of atoms through crystals, along grain boundaries, and through pore fluids. Source: Neuendorf, K.K.E, Mehl, J.P. & Jackson, J.A. (eds), 2005. Glossary of geology, 5th Edition. American Geological Institute, Alexandria, 779 p.
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:EventProcess:200811:diffusion_creep
ControlledConcept.name: diffusion creep

ControlledConcept.gml:description: Deformation by dissolution under the effects of differential stress and its transport to a new location by movement of fluid in the rock body. Source: Neuendorf, K.K.E, Mehl, J.P. & Jackson, J.A. (eds), 2005. Glossary of geology, 5th Edition. American Geological Institute, Alexandria, 779 p.
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:EventProcess:200811:dissolution_creep
ControlledConcept.name: dissolution creep

ControlledConcept.gml:description: deformation in which planar surfaces become regularly curviplanar surfaces with definable limbs (zones of lower curvature) and hinges (zones of higher curvature). Source: this vocabulary
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:EventProcess:200811:folding
ControlledConcept.name: folding

ControlledConcept.gml:description: The process or group of processes by which earth materials exposed to atmospheric agents at or near the Earth's surface are changed in color, texture, composition, firmness, or form, with little or no transport of the loosened or altered material. Processes typically include oxidation, hydration, and leaching of soluble constituents. Source: this vocabulary
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:EventProcess:200811:weathering
ControlledConcept.name: weathering

ControlledConcept.gml:description: The process of weathering by which frost action, salt-crystal growth, absorption of water, and other physical processes break down a rock to fragments, involving no chemical change Source: Neuendorf, K.K.E, Mehl, J.P. & Jackson, J.A. (eds), 2005. Glossary of geology, 5th Edition. American Geological Institute, Alexandria, 779 p.
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:EventProcess:200811:physical_weathering
ControlledConcept.name: physical weathering

ControlledConcept.gml:description: propagation of fractures near the surface of solid rock due to expansion and contraction caused by temperature changes. Fractures typically propagate along surfaces close to and subparallel to the surface of the outcrop. Source: this vocabulary
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:EventProcess:200811:thermal_shock_weathering
ControlledConcept.name: thermal shock weathering

ControlledConcept.gml:description: propagation of fractures near the surface of solid rock due to expansion related to release of confining pressure when deeply buried rock is unroofed. Fractures typically propagate along surfaces close to and subparallel to the surface of the outcrop. Source: Neuendorf, K.K.E, Mehl, J.P. & Jackson, J.A. (eds), 2005. Glossary of geology, 5th Edition. American Geological Institute, Alexandria, 779 p.
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:EventProcess:200811:pressure_release_weathering
ControlledConcept.name: pressure release weathering

ControlledConcept.gml:description: Propagation of fractures due to expansion of freezing water in intergranular spaces and fractures in a rock body. Result is mechanical disintegration spliitting, or breakup of rock. Source: Neuendorf, K.K.E, Mehl, J.P. & Jackson, J.A. (eds), 2005. Glossary of geology, 5th Edition. American Geological Institute, Alexandria, 779 p.
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:EventProcess:200811:frost_shattering
ControlledConcept.name: frost shattering

ControlledConcept.gml:description: propagation of fractures in rock due to crytallization of mineral salts (typically sodium chloride) from interstitial water, or volumetrick expansion of salts in capillaries, or hydration pressure of interstitial, trapped salts. Generally results in mechanical disintegration of the rock surface. Source: Neuendorf, K.K.E, Mehl, J.P. & Jackson, J.A. (eds), 2005. Glossary of geology, 5th Edition. American Geological Institute, Alexandria, 779 p.
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:EventProcess:200811:haloclasty
ControlledConcept.name: haloclasty

ControlledConcept.gml:description: The process of weathering by which chemical reactions (hydrolysis, hydration, oxidation, carbonation, ion exchange, and solution) transform rocks and minerals into new chemical combinations that are stable under conditions prevailing at or near the Earth's surface; e.g. the alteration of orthoclase to kaolinite. Source: Neuendorf, K.K.E, Mehl, J.P. & Jackson, J.A. (eds), 2005. Glossary of geology, 5th Edition. American Geological Institute, Alexandria, 779 p.
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:EventProcess:200811:chemical_weathering
ControlledConcept.name: chemical weathering

ControlledConcept.gml:description: The process of dissolving into a homogenous solution, as when an acidic solution dissolves limestone. In karst, refers to the process of dissolving rock to produce landforms, in contrast to solution, the chemical product of dissolution. Source: Neuendorf, K.K.E, Mehl, J.P. & Jackson, J.A. (eds), 2005. Glossary of geology, 5th Edition. American Geological Institute, Alexandria, 779 p.
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:EventProcess:200811:dissolution
ControlledConcept.name: dissolution

ControlledConcept.gml:description: The process of absorption of water into the crystal structure of a mineral, thereby changing its volume and fracturing and loosening grains Source: this vocabulary
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:EventProcess:200811:hydration
ControlledConcept.name: hydration

ControlledConcept.gml:description: A decomposition reaction involving water. In geology, it commonly indicates reaction between silicate minerals and either pure water or aqueous solution. In such reactions, H Source: Neuendorf, K.K.E, Mehl, J.P. & Jackson, J.A. (eds), 2005. Glossary of geology, 5th Edition. American Geological Institute, Alexandria, 779 p.
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:EventProcess:200811:hydrolysis
ControlledConcept.name: hydrolysis

ControlledConcept.gml:description: Chemical reaction that involve stripping of electrons from cations. Typicall reactions include converting sulfide minerals to oxide minerals, or increasing the oxidation state of cations in existing oxide minerals. The most commonly observed is the oxidation of Fe Source: this vocabulary
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:EventProcess:200811:oxidation
ControlledConcept.name: oxidation

ControlledConcept.gml:description: breakdown of rocks by biological agents, e.g. the penetrating and expanding force of roots, the presence of moss and lichen causing humic acids to be retained in contact with rock, and the work of animals (worms, moles, rabbits) in modifying surface soil Source: Neuendorf, K.K.E, Mehl, J.P. & Jackson, J.A. (eds), 2005. Glossary of geology, 5th Edition. American Geological Institute, Alexandria, 779 p.
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:EventProcess:200811:biological_weathering
ControlledConcept.name: biological weathering

ControlledConcept.gml:description: processes of human modification of the earth to produce geologic features Source: this vocabulary
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:EventProcess:200811:human_activity
ControlledConcept.name: Human activity

ControlledConcept.gml:description: leveling of earth surface by rearrangement of prexisting material Source: this vocabulary
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:EventProcess:200811:grading
ControlledConcept.name: grading

ControlledConcept.gml:description: transport and heaping of material, as in a land fill, mine dump, dredging operations Source: this vocabulary
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:EventProcess:200811:material_transport_and_deposition
ControlledConcept.name: material transport and deposition

ControlledConcept.gml:description: removal of material, as in a mining operation Source: this vocabulary
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:EventProcess:200811:excavation
ControlledConcept.name: excavation

ControlledConcept.gml:description: the impact of an extraterrestrial body on the surface of the earth Source: this vocabulary
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:EventProcess:200811:bolide_impact
ControlledConcept.name: bolide impact

ControlledConcept.gml:description: the impact of a comet on the surface of the earth Source: this vocabulary
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:EventProcess:200811:cometary_impact
ControlledConcept.name: cometary impact

ControlledConcept.gml:description: the impact of a meteorite on the surface of the earth Source: this vocabulary
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:EventProcess:200811:meteorite_impact
ControlledConcept.name: meteorite impact
